_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of AgVantage FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Alburnett Fire Department,Linn County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and environment.

2.The stationary source and the regulated substance handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 2686 Old Quass Rd, Alburnett, IA is the storage and blending of fertilizer for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of a gallon storage tank, loading risers, railroad cars associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 

3.The worst-case scenario and the alternative release scenario.

This facility has developed a worst-case and alternative-case scenario, however, since this is security-sensitive information it has been withheld from this Executive Summary as required by EPA regulations.

4.The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration
(OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program

.

5.Historical information on this facility.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years , that to our knowledge have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, or environmental damage.

6.The emergency response program.

This facility has:
-A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard,29 CFR 1910.38:
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

7. Planned changes to improve safety.
             
In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify  Alburnett Fire Department and Linn Co.  LEPC and request that they both respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.
